post_with_time: "60% of interns become full-time employees -Hiring paid interns is an easy process that transforms how companies build their talent pipeline. The numbers speak for themselves - 60% of interns move into full-time roles, creating a direct path to permanent employment.Â¹Students show remarkable success rates. Within just three months of graduating, 87% of former interns land jobs, demonstrating how these programs effectively kickstart careers.Â²Companies can bring in eager individuals who contribute creative ideas and tackle various projects right away. These interns often become valuable long-term team members while providing fresh perspectives.Â¹Here's what makes paid internships a smart investment:- Cut down hiring and training costs- Get an extended look at potential hires- Keep employees longer- Speed up new hire trainingÂ¹For students, it's real work experience that counts. This hands-on experience helps them transition smoothly from classroom to workplace.Â²Our fall 2025 CO-OP work term hiring process is open and ongoing. "The Intern" â€“ A Lesson on the Untapped Potential of Experienced TalentA while back, I watched the movie *The Intern*, and it resonated deeply with me. It wasnâ€™t just entertainmentâ€”it felt like a reflection of my own story. Having worked with an international airline that upheld exceptional business ethics, a professional team, and world-class HR standards, I know firsthand the value of experience, passion, and dedication.This film is a reminder of something we often overlook in the corporate world: the immense potential of experienced professionals who are eager to restart their careers.Many retireesâ€”myself includedâ€”are not just willing but passionate about contributing again. We bring decades of expertise, stability, and a strong work ethic that can create synergy when combined with fresh, qualified talent.Yet, in Pakistan (and elsewhere), thousands of skilled professionals retire every yearâ€”many of whom are ready to continue working immediately or after a short break. The best part? This experienced talent is often available at a fraction of the cost of hiring a fresh but inexperienced resource.So, hereâ€™s my appeal to HR professionals and business leaders:- Revisit your hiring strategies â€“ Donâ€™t let institutional knowledge walk out the door.- Leverage the power of mentorship â€“ A mix of youth and experience drives innovation.- Consider flexible roles â€“ Many retirees seek meaningful work, not just a paycheck.If you havenâ€™t watched *The Intern*, I highly recommend itâ€”not just as a movie but as a case study on why experience matters. Extremely sad to see how cheap the professionals are getting in the name of new media. I understand the market is hard but you can't exploit talent with rotten budgets.Are there still organizations hiring experienced & versatile talent with a decent pay range? This makes me sad.With all those responsibilities, the paycheck is basically 1/3rd of what it should be. Expertise doesn't come for free. I'm sure a lot of people are facing the same issue as me, shrunken paychecks.In fact, recently, a random beat officer began messaging me weird stuff out of the blue. Bros, where has your mental filter gone?We already don't have a lot of women leaders to look up to & to see the culture stooping down to this, it's crushing.Interns are exploited for months with peanuts. Extremely saddened by this current state of affairs. No wonder people are jamming up the directory for Peon jobs, it's probably their small act of resistance.I'm only aware of 3 people whose mothers work & everyone else I'm aware of go with the housewife tag, including the women in my own family. Setting such a terrible precedent for the upcoming generation.Women are an important part of the workforce, this is how creative roles are treated. I'm crying tears of blood. The organizations are as supportive of my veteran skills as my mother was of my choice of college & street dogs.Is this the recession, someone just confirm please! Finishing my academic career at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln has also marked the end of my time as a student intern at HuskerVision. I canâ€™t begin to say enough about how much this role has taught me in the last two years and how many unforgettable opportunities I was given with it. Hiring someone who had no idea on how to use a camera was probably not the safest decision, but it will definitely not be forgotten. I owe you all more than a thank you for the guidance and inspiration to make great things in this pursuit of a career. Looking back on the projects from my time here, I think this senior tribute best exemplifies my gratitude, and represents how much of a foundation Iâ€™ve gained. Because of the impactful two years working around the great people at HuskerVision, I canâ€™t wait to see whatâ€™s next. For HR InternJob Title: HR InternCompany: Wonton Consulting Private Limited (WCPL)Location: RemoteDuration: 2 MonthsStipend: Performance-basedAbout WCPL:Wonton Consulting Private Limited (WCPL) is a fast-growing HR consulting and talent solutions firm dedicated to transforming how organizations manage and develop their workforce. We specialize in recruitment, HR strategy, talent development, and workforce planning across various industries. At WCPL, we are passionate about nurturing young talent and creating a learning environment that blends theoretical knowledge with real-world HR practices.Internship Overview:WCPL is looking for a dynamic and proactive *HR Intern* to support our Human Resource operations. This 2-month internship is ideal for students or recent graduates eager to gain practical experience in core HR functions within a professional consulting setup. Hiring managers aren't ghosting you for fun. They're not looking to unleash workplace soft skill disasters. And honestly? We get it.From LinkedIn:89% of failed hires are due to bad soft skills.92% of talent practitioners say that soft skills are as critical or more critical than hard skills.Only 41% of companies have a process to assess them.Most are being hired based on what they know and let go based on who they are. You might be able to learn technical skills to get a job, but without soft skills, you could lose it. No one wants to work with the guy who thinks"teamwork" means everyone else does all the work, or the intern who emails about work like it's a WhatsApp conversation:"Hae, plz do the thing asap thx"Introducing ZydiiMicrolearning soft skills training for African teams, delivered to your phone.From communication and teamwork to time management and leadership, we help teams drop bad work habits without putting them to sleep.Because let's be real, no one has time for a 3-hour PowerPoint presentation on emotional intelligence.Our Microlearning Magic1. Fun, brief modules (2 to 10 minutes)2. Mobile-first, so you can learn on the go3. Real African workplace scenarios with no corporate speak4. Functional, not preachy, and sometimes humorous5. How the hell am I supposed to justify hiring an intern or recent graduate in 2025?I already hear the agentic AI consortium laughing me out of timeline relevance as they vibe-code their way to another few million ARR (or at least a viral LinkedIn post).Iâ€™m not the only one worried.Aneesh Ramanâ€™s recent opinion inThe New York Times(https://lnkd.in/eNtFe_Rt) does a great job explaining how the outsourcing of simple tasks to AI, rather than juniors, removes a critical way that young workers gain experience.If I didnâ€™t write hundreds of 160-character long promotional SMSs every month forJosÃ© Soaresback in 2013, or labour over monthly performance reports with (admittedly basic) Excel analysis, I doubt my LinkedIn ads would be among LinkedInâ€™s top 1% performers a decade later.We're fighting over academic talent (see the recentHarvard Universityvs Trump international student drama). But I wonder what weâ€™ll do with that talent once they graduate. Deeptech research may consider itself safe, but after reading AI 2027 (https://ai-2027.com/) I wonder how long good â€œresearch appetiteâ€ will protect them.I donâ€™t have answers to the above grand challenges, but I do discuss how marketing can tackle this today with clients, as well asGrowthMentormentees, regularly. My advice:â–¶ï¸ Split marketing into three pillars: Strategy, Production (writing content, building landing pages, launching digital campaigns), Operations (arranging events, submitting award proposals, setting up CRM workflows).â–¶ï¸ Your Marketing leader should be doing all three. While significant time is spent on strategy, leadership should produce and run some operations to maintain perspective.â–¶ï¸ Experts handle the bulk of production. These can be in-house FTEs, agencies, freelancers or even AI agents, but the goal is top quality driven by deep experience.â–¶ï¸ Operations is where interns and recent graduates can shine because mindset and execution, rather than hard-skills and knowledge, are the success factors. Exposure to domain experts and real-world scenarios accelerates the transition from academia to a career.The above should help fresh faces into the marketing workforce, upskill rapidly through exposure, and benefit from their creative thinking.It might not be as efficient over the short term as â€œAI everythingâ€, but Iâ€™d letKlarnaCEOSebastian Siemiatkowski's recentBloomberginterview end with a note on cost vs. quality:Siemiatkowski said that [an all-in on AI for customer support] strategy isnâ€™t the right fit any more. â€œAs cost unfortunately seems to have been a too predominant evaluation factor when organizing this, what you end up having is lower quality,â€ he said. â€œReally investing in the quality of the human support is the way of the future for us.â€How do we blend quality, cost-efficiency, and social obligation to the next generation of talent together? Start by Reaching Out to Professionalsâ€¢ Target analysts, associates, or VPs at boutique or mid-market IB firmsâ€¢ These firms often hire off-cycle interns through networks and referralsâ€¢ Focus on building real connections, not just asking for a job2. Ask for Informational InterviewsRequest 15â€“20 mins to understand:â€¢ Their career journeyâ€¢ Their day-to-day workâ€¢ Industry insights you canâ€™t find on Googleâ€¢ This builds trust and shows youâ€™re genuinely interested3. Share Your Work to Prove Commitmentâ€¢ Work on a basic financial model, do industry research, and turn it into a short presentationâ€¢ Share it and ask for feedback, this shows youâ€™re not just interested, but preparedâ€¢ When you ask for help, they should already know you're capable4. INTERNSHIP APPLICATION FOR THE PLATINUM AND TAYLOR HILL LP VIRTUAL INTERNSHIP PROGRAMME 3.0.The Hiring Manager,I write to express my interest as an intern in the Pth Virtual Internship Programme 3.0.It is fact that legal education is a rather complex one not limited to academic activities and the like,and at such opens its horizons to other activities that enhances professional development, of which internship is an ideal,thus indulging one to work towards personal developments,skills and experience geared towards one's intended line of specialty.I am currently a 200 level student, pursuing a degree in law at Imo State University, Owerri, Nigeria.My academic journey has been one loaded with great developments through researches and writings, coupled with my academic commitment and dedication,evident in my glowing CGPA,and an award of excellence as the overall winner at a chamber Essay Writing Competition.With great interests in Advocacy and Human rights activism, Corporate law,and the evolving Ai and the law,I am confident that this platform will serve as a resourceful catalyst to these interests,through insightful experiences and mentorships while benefiting immensely from my invaluable skills and abilities as I am a quick learner,an eager personality and one open to wholesome opportunities.Thanks for considering my application,I anticipate a favourable response. Interns Are Not Coffee Runners Theyâ€™re Future CEOs in TrainingMany companies still see internships as a form of cheap, temporary labor, but this mindset is outdated and costly.Interns represent untapped potential.They are the future innovators, managers, and executives.Treating them like low-level assistants misses a critical opportunity to shape your organizationâ€™s success.Why Internships Matter More Than EverWith fast-changing markets and new business models, companies need agile and adaptable leaders.Internship programs that are strategic and thoughtfully designed become talent accelerators transforming raw potential into real leadership.How to Build a Program That WorksğŸ¯ It Starts with a PlanDevelop a clear structure: Define what skills and experiences interns will gain. Set goals for their contribution and learning milestones. Treat interns as early-career professionals rather than temporary helpers.ğŸ¤ It Grows with MentorshipPair interns with mentors who can provide guidance and feedback. Mentorship builds confidence and helps interns navigate their roles and the company culture.ğŸš€ It Flourishes with Real Work and Honest FeedbackAssign interns meaningful projects that impact business outcomes. Encourage an environment where feedback is frequent, specific, and supportive. This combination boosts skills and motivation.The ResultInterns who feel valued and challenged are more engaged and productive. They become natural advocates for your brand and are more likely to join full-time, reducing your hiring risk.More importantly, you create a leadership pipeline that feeds your company with skilled and culturally aligned talent ready to take on tomorrowâ€™s challenges.An internship program isnâ€™t an expense itâ€™s an investment in your companyâ€™s future. The interns you nurture today will shape your leadership tomorrow. Let's talk about those "We're hiring freshers!" posts flooding your feed lately... ğŸš©You know the ones:â€¢ Professional photo of someone(usually a somewhat pretty girl) in formal attire ğŸ‘”â€¢ Big corporate logo as the backdrop ğŸ¢â€¢ Caption screaming "Comment 'INTERESTED' to get shortlist!" âœï¸â€¢ Zero job description, no requirements, no application processHere's what's actually happening:These aren't legitimate recruitment efforts. They're engagement traps designed to harvest your data and boost someone's profile metrics. The person in the photo often doesn't even know their image is being used for this purpose.As someone who values genuine professional connections and has seen the real hiring process from both sides, this trend is concerning. Job seekers, especially freshers, deserve better than to have their hopes manipulated for social media engagement.Think about it: No reputable company asks candidates to "comment interested" as part of their application process.Real recruiters provide:â€¢ Clear job descriptionsâ€¢ Qualification requirementsâ€¢ Application instructionsâ€¢ Company informationCredit toShubhamfor highlighting this issue.If you're a job seeker, especially a fresher, please protect your time and data:â€¢ Request complete job details before engagingâ€¢ Check if the poster is actually connected to the company they claim be part ofâ€¢ Look for verification on the company's official career pageâ€¢ Be wary of posts asking only for comments rather than proper applicationsLet's keep LinkedIn a place for real professional opportunities, not engagement farming.And a note to theLinkedInTrust & Safety Team... LinkedOut Diariesâ„¢ â€“ Entry #022Title: How to Survive a 4-Round Interview Process That Ends in Ghosting (Spoiler: You Donâ€™t)I went through four rounds.FOUR.Four interviews. Four fake laughs. Four outfit changes I couldnâ€™t afford to wash again. One unpaid task that took three hours and a small piece of my soul.And you know what I got at the end of it all?Absolutely nothing. Not even a â€œsorry.â€Just a slow, painful ghosting that haunts me like a bad situationship I thought was â€œdifferent.â€Letâ€™s break it down, shall we?ROUND ONE: The Flirt.They slid into my inbox with â€œWe were really impressed with your application!â€And I believed them. Like a fool.I showed up smiley and prepared. I said words like â€œsynergyâ€ and â€œimpactâ€ while sitting on a broken chair. I thought, â€œOh wow, they like me.â€Ha. Cute.ROUND TWO: The Vibe Check.â€œLetâ€™s meet the team!â€I met the team. I charmed the team. I emotionally bonded with the team. I started imagining what my Slack profile photo would look like.They said things like:â€œYouâ€™re a strong candidate.â€â€œWe love your energy.â€Translation: they were already hiring someone else but felt bad about it.ROUND THREE: The Task.â€œYouâ€™ll just need to complete a short assignment.â€It was neither short, nor sane.It was 6 pages of strategy, three pages of writing, a spreadsheet, and a tiny existential crisis.I did it.Because Iâ€™m desperate. Because Iâ€™m a try-hard. Because I still believe work should feel meaningful.I even edited it in Canva so it would look pretty while they ignored it.ROUND FOUR: The Final Interviewâ„¢I put on my good earrings.I said the word â€œpassionateâ€ four times.I referenced their mission statement. I even said I liked teamwork.I was lying through my teeth, but I did it with a smile because thatâ€™s what capitalism demands.And then?Nothing.No rejection. No â€œweâ€™ve moved on.â€ No â€œthank you for your time.â€Just âœ¨ghostedâœ¨ like I never existed.And the worst part?I STILL CHECKED MY EMAIL FOR WEEKS.Like a fool. Like a love-struck intern waiting for their boss to notice them.The level of emotional whiplash this process gave me could fund an entire therapy arc.Conclusion?If your hiring process is going to be longer than a mini-series, the bare minimum you can do is send a freaking email at the end.This wasnâ€™t just rejection.It was a slow-motion heartbreak served cold and silent.And now I walk through life with a permanent dent in my hope.So yeah, I survived. Barely.And if you're reading this while waiting to hear back from your own Fourth Round Fiascoâ„¢, just know:You deserved better.You still do.hashtag#LinkedOutDiarieshashtag#GhostedAfterRoundFourhashtag#HireMeOrDonâ€™tButSaySomethinghashtag#ThisIsABreakupPostNowhashtag#OpenToWorkAndEmotionalReparations Mitchelle WambuiMitchelle Wambui LinkedOut Diariesâ„¢ â€“ Entry #022Title: How to Survive a 4-Round Interview Process That Ends in Ghosting (Spoiler: You Donâ€™t)I went through four rounds.FOUR.Four interviews. Networking as a fresher in the job market can feel challenging, but it's very doable with the right approach. Here are practical steps to build your network:1. Leverage Your Existing ConnectionsTalk to lecturers, classmates, and alumni â€” they may have job leads or know someone hiring.Ask for referrals â€” a warm introduction is often more effective than cold outreach.2. Use LinkedIn EffectivelyCreate a professional profile with a clear headline and summary.Connect with industry professionals, recruiters, and company employees.Engage with posts by commenting or sharing insights to become visible.3. Attend Career Events and WorkshopsUniversity career fairs, webinars, and industry meetups are goldmines for networking.Follow up with people you meet: send a polite message or email thanking them and expressing interest.4. Join Professional GroupsLook for WhatsApp, Telegram, or Facebook groups related to your field (e.g., tech, accounting, marketing).Also consider professional associations or student chapters (e.g., IEEE, ISK, PRSK, etc.).5. Volunteer or InternEven unpaid roles can build experience and introduce you to professionals who might recommend you later.6. Be Curious and Ask QuestionsWhen meeting professionals, ask about their career paths, challenges, and advice for beginners.People often enjoy talking about themselves and appreciate genuine interest.7. Stay in TouchDonâ€™t disappear after connecting. Share updates, congratulate people on milestones, or just check in occasionally. Some job search stories are tough, this is one of those.I frequently help single parents get hired and this story is one of the tougher ones.If you're not sure hope and prayer can make a difference, they still do.Earlier this year I helped a parent going thru divorce who now also had to find a job not by choice.That hurts.Besides divorce she had not worked outside the home in 15 years.That means no resume. Strike 1.No outside job experience to show dependability. Strike 2The rest of the story is that in a few days we developed a resume showing her computer skills & soft skills.She learned what is important to employers in choosing a new hire this year & how to present it that was impressive.She applied for a job in a medical clinic not as an office intern but as the person making appointments, scheduling, and greeting new patients.You probably think "no way that's going to happen!".That was in the afternoon. The next morning she was offered and accepted the job.Don't give up on your goal of getting hired. The Exploitation No One Talks About: Unpaid Internships in Pakistanâ€™s Corporate SectorUnpaid internships are glamorized slavery and itâ€™s time we say it like it is.Every year, thousands of students in Pakistan hustle for a foot in the door, only to land internships that promise exposure instead of fair compensation. In reality, what theyâ€™re exposed to is a broken system that thrives on free labor while preaching about â€œyouth empowerment.â€Letâ€™s talk numbers. Convincing your family to let you work for free is hard enough but commuting, meals, clothing, and basic survival in a city like Lahore or Karachi easily costs PKR 15,000 to 30,000 a month. Thatâ€™s the price students silently pay just to add a line on their CV.Companies that pride themselves on profitability still somehow expect students to work 9 to 5 without a single rupee in return. Not even a stipend for transport. No contribution to phone bills. Just the illusion of opportunity.Meanwhile, the ones who can afford these internships often belong to privileged backgrounds widening the already massive gap between the haves and have-nots. Talent becomes a matter of access, not merit.If a company cannot afford to pay interns, it shouldn't be hiring them in the first place. Period.It's time we stop romanticizing unpaid internships and start calling them what they are: corporate exploitation hiding behind fancy job titles. Why are freshers struggling to get a job?Major tech giants (Google, Microsoft, Meta, Apple, Tesla, Palantir, Nvidia) have recorded ZERO net headcount growth since 2022. Our Indian IT companies thankfully are still hiring but only because they are investing in the future.Compare that to the pandemic hiring frenzy when these companies added 120,000+ employees in a single year.What changed? 4 key factors:ğŸ”¸ Pandemic Overhiring Hangover - Companies are still digesting their 2020-2022 hiring spree as demand normalizedğŸ”¸ Rising Interest Rates - CFOs prioritizing margin discipline over headcount expansionğŸ”¸ AI Infrastructure Investment - Billions diverted to GPUs and data centers, leaving less for junior hiresğŸ”¸ AI Replacing Entry-Level Work - Copilots and automation tools enabling teams to do more with lessThe traditional link between revenue growth and headcount growth is breaking. Companies are testing whether they can grow without growing their teams.For freshers navigating this storm:âœ… Build portfolios, not just rÃ©sumÃ©sâœ… Master AI tools in your fieldâœ… Freelance/intern strategicallyâœ… Network beyond LinkedInâœ… Target smaller companies and emerging sectorsThe job market isn't brokenâ€”it's evolving. The future belongs to those who adapt early, learn fast, and stay visible. Reach out to us atBe Practical Tech Solutionsto understand how we are playing our role in creating such graduates.But here's the real truth - freshers who understand AI, build real projects, and think like founders aren't just employableâ€”they're unstoppable. _Navigating the world of HR: Empathy vs. Experience ğŸ’¼_My first week as an HR Intern has been a fascinating journey into the realities of recruitment. My background as a customer service representative instilled in me a deep sense of empathy â€“ putting myself in others' shoes  â€“ the ability to truly understand and share the feelings of others. Stepping into an HR role, I initially assumed this skill would directly translate.One early challenge has been reviewing countless CVs, many from individuals who, despite their enthusiasm, don't quite meet the specific requirements for the roles we're currently hiring for. It brings a certain sadness having to turn down these applications. The thought often crosses my mind: "People can learn and grow on the job, can't we offer them a chance, even if their experience isn't a perfect match? Everyone has to start somewhere, right?"I voiced this very question to my boss: "Why can't we process and submit CVs for roles that applicants are passionate about, even if they don't fully meet the stated criteria? Surely, a CV doesn't capture someone's full potential."Her response provided valuable perspective, framed by a simple yet impactful scenario: "If I were a business owner with little or no knowledge of handling social media space seeking a Social Media Manager with a specific level of proven experience, would it be wise to hire someone with absolutely no prior experience in that field?" The answer, undeniably, was "no."This conversation has illuminated a crucial aspect of HR: while empathy is essential in understanding the aspirations of job seekers, effective recruitment also demands a level of strategic discretion to meet the specific needs and goals of the organization.This early stage of my HR journey is already teaching me the importance of this balance. It's about recognizing potential while also ensuring the right fit for the role. A valuable lesson learned indeed!what are your thoughts on this? kindly enlighten this internhashtag#HRhashtag#Internshiphashtag#RecruitmentProcesshashtag#EmpathyInHRhashtag#ProfessionalDevelopmenthashtag#JobRequirementshashtag#HRInternhashtag#Recruitmenthashtag#LearningandGrowthhashtag#HumanResources Favour AnozieFavour Anozie _Navigating the world of HR: Empathy vs. Experience ğŸ’¼_My first week as an HR Intern has been a fascinating journey into the realities of recruitment. hashtag#hiring*Architectural Intern*, Calgary, *Canada*, fulltimehashtag#opentoworkhashtag#Calgaryjobshashtag#Albertajobshashtag#Constructionhashtag#entrylevelhashtag#firstjobhashtag#newgradhashtag#internshiphashtag#entryleveljobs*To Apply -->*:https://lnkd.in/djpFVybyFor over four decades, Evans has been the global leader in providing innovative solutions for mission-critical operations. We serve a diverse client base, including public safety, aviation, process control, utilities, and technology, as well as numerous government agencies. With the industry's largest portfolio of projects worldwide, serving 15 industries, it's our proven methodology, strict quality standards, and experience that make the difference for our customers. Looking for an Architectural Technologist (Level 2) to join our expanding Construction Team in Calgary, AB.The Architectural Intern will work under the supervision of the Project Architect as an integral member of a Design Team specializing in the development of high-quality design solutions across a multitude of industries. This role provides an opportunity to gain hands-on experience in space programming, field surveying, architectural + interior design, detailed computer modelling, and construction documentation + administration. Proficient in Revit, the ideal candidate is curious, self-driven, appreciates variety in project types and location, and has the discipline to work both independently and as part of a team.Key ResponsibilitiesAssist in producing conceptual drawings based on sketches, notes, and Client communicationsSupport the development of schematic design, design intent, and construction document packagesCoordinate with Architects, Engineers, Construction Project Managers, and other project stakeholdersUnderstand applicable building codes, ADA compliance, and permitting requirementsConduct site surveys and document as-built conditions for existing spacesSupport custom millwork design by creating schematic drawingsPrepare color board finish options and material selectionsResearch construction materials and product specificationsParticipate in design review meetingsProvide administrative support,Communicate regularly with the Project Team to identify and resolve design challenges and maintain project schedulesOther Duties IncludeAttending client and consultant meetings as neededUpdating and maintaining internal Revit templates and standard detailsAssisting with occasional site visits to observe and document project progressEducation/ExperienceCompleted Bachelor of Architecture or Master of Architecture Previous internship or co-op experience in an architectural or design firm is considered an assetEvans is an Equal Opportunity Employer.Our mission is to ensure that our workforce is both diverse and inclusiveWe seek employees from a diverse talent group, if you are a member of a minority population, we encourage you to apply at Evans!
